newsitem.title: GERMANY: Russia and NATO still far apart on enlargement.
newsitem.headline: Russia and NATO still far apart on enlargement.

text.p: Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov committed Moscow on Wednesday to a dialogue with the West about Europe's new security structures, but said Russia remained opposed to NATO's expansion.

"Our position (on extending NATO) has not changed. But we also think it is necessary to have security talks to establish the relations between NATO and Russia," he told a news conference after meeting German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel.
Primakov, making first bilateral visit to the West since taking office in January, was due to meet Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Thursday.

Kinkel had billed Wednesday's meeting as the start of a period of intensive talks between Russia and the West to agree a formal charter or treaty governing their relations. Kohl is due to meet Russian President Boris Yeltsin in Mocsow on Saturday.
NATO is likely to decide in principle early next year to admit Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, all formerly part of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, as members.

Russia remains opposed to seeing the Western alliance extend to its borders. But Primakov appeared to soften this stance in June when he suggested a limited expansion might be acceptable if no troops or weapons were stationed on the territory of new members.
While NATO has insisted it will not grant Russia a veto an newadmissions, Germany is pushing for a formal framework which would ensure Russia is involved and consulted on such decisions.
Primakov, stressing the confidence existing between Germany and Russia, said: "I am glad to say we agreed that there can be no European security without Russia."
Kinkel said both countries agreed on a need to strengthen the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe by giving it new conflict-prevention powers at an OSCE summit in Lisbon in December.

But they differed sharply on their assessment of the U.S. air strikes against Iraq, intended to punish Baghdad for sending its forces to attack against Kurds in a U.N.-implemented no-fly area in the north of the country.
Bonn has said the attacks are appropriate, but Primakov criticised them sharply for the third time in two days. "It's a very dangerous situation, a precedent for the future," he said.

"If... we have a superpower, be it the United States, Europe or Russia, acting on its own initiative to use violence in a region without consulting an international organisation, in this case the U.N. Security Council, there will be conflict."
Kinkel said his talks with Primakov also covered the health of Yeltsin, seen in public only once since late June.
Yeltsin's aides say his low profile is not a sign of failing health or a lack of control over policy, but that he needs rest and is limiting his meetings and calls.
"We wish for him that he will soon again find the strength -- and I am sure he will, we talked about that -- to take on government business in the way that we jointly hope for," Kinkel said.
